thread.title: Man fatally shot by police in Affton was a former officer
thread.title_full: Man fatally shot by police in Affton was a former officer

author: Denise Hollinshed • St. Louis Post-Dispatch
title: Man fatally shot by police in Affton was a former officer
text:
+2 
Clifton Knickmeyer, in a photo from his LinkedIn profile. 
A St. Louis County police officer fatally shot a man in this house in the 8700 block of Zellwood Drive in Affton after the man drew a gun on the officer inside the home, police said. Police were called to the house in the early morning hours of March 19, 2017, for a domestic dispute. Photo by Denise Hollinshed, dhollinshed@post-dispatch.com. 
Clifton Knickmeyer, in a photo from Facebook 
A man killed early Sunday by St. Louis County police responding to a domestic dispute in the Affton area had once been a police officer in the St. Louis area. 
Clifton Knickmeyer, 59, who lived in the 8700 block of Zellwood Drive, was fatally shot after police arrived at the home about 1:15 a.m. Sunday on a domestic violence call. 
A woman, 58, who lives at the home, was fighting with Knickmeyer, her boyfriend, authorities said. 
The woman and her son, 26, met arriving officers at the house, west of where Union Road crosses Interstate 55. The woman told police the disturbance was verbal and became physical when she called police. She told officers Knickmeyer was in the bedroom. 
According to police, officers announced their presence when they entered the home. They found Knickmeyer standing next to a bed in a bedroom. They spoke to him and tried to calm the situation, St. Louis County Police Chief Jon Belmar said at an early-morning press conference. 
Knickmeyer reached under the bedding, and the officers ordered him to show his hands, Belmar said. He raised a semi-automatic handgun and pointed the gun at an officer. The officer then fired several times with his department handgun, striking Knickmeyer. 
Knickmeyer was pronounced dead at the scene. Officers recovered a gun in his possession. 
The officer who shot Knickmeyer has been with the county police department for four years, authorities said. 
“It’s tragic that this type of occurrence would happen, but these officers have no other choice but to defend their lives,” Belmar said. 
The shooting remains under investigation. Police spent much of the day at the house, taking crime-scene tape down about 6 p.m. 
Knickmeyer had worked for various police departments over the years and was a certified weapons instructor, according to his LinkedIn profile. Among those departments is Ballwin. 
“We became aware of the involvement of Clifton Knickmeyer in this morning’s incident,” said detective Scott Stephens, a Ballwin Police spokesman. “Clifton Knickmeyer’s employment with the Ballwin Police Department ended over a decade ago and he has not been involved in the organization since.” 
According to state records and his LinkedIn profile, Knickmeyer also started several businesses including a company called Freedom Force Security & Defense, which was described as a security consultant for homes, families and workplaces. Its website is no longer active. 
Some neighbors said that they believed Knickmeyer and the woman had been together for a few months; another said about a year. They said he was typically seen going in and out of the house wearing a white cowboy hat. 
His Facebook page — with a cover image proclaiming the “Cowboy Code of Conduct” — includes photos of him with the woman. 
Christine Byers and Joel Currier of the Post-Dispatch contributed to this report. +2
